"The Interview (2014 film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "467209", "score": 1}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Last_Week_Tonight_with_John_Oliver", "label": {"eng": "Last Week Tonight with John Oliver"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "476019", "score": 4}], "time": "01:58:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Last week, as HBO investigated a cyberattack on its own systems, an unaired episode of its hit show 'Game of Thrones' appeared online following an unrelated breach at a pay-TV partner in India. -- Reuters picLOS ANGELES, Aug 13 -- Sony. Netflix. And now, HBO.\n\nWhile the 2014 hacking at Sony Pictures pushed entertainment giants to take computer security more seriously, recent incidents have exposed weaknesses throughout Hollywood's food chain. Last week, as HBO investigated a cyberattack on its own systems, an unaired episode of its hit show Game of Thrones appeared online following an unrelated breach at a pay-TV partner in India. In April, when 10 episodes of Netflix Inc's Orange Is the New Black leaked, the incident was traced to a contractor.\n\nCybercrime is a growing problem for many industries, but Hollywood is especially vulnerable because of the long chain of people who work on a show or movie in post-production, experts say. Studios rely on an army of freelancers for everything from special effects to musical scores, creating a vast network of targets for hackers. Bringing those workers in-house is an option but would be expensive and could limit the talent studios can tap.\n\n\"Hollywood will have to recognise this will continue to grow and be an issue,\" said Mike Orosz, who studies cyber risk as research director at the University of Southern California's Information Sciences Institute.\n\nHBO requires employees to have two-factor authentication and strong passwords for their computers. They also undergo security awareness training. But the company works with many post-production freelancers that handle sensitive information on personal email accounts and personal devices, raising security concerns, according to a former employee who asked not to be identified discussing an internal matter.\n\n\"Once the content is out of your hands, it's truly out of your hands,\" Orosz said. \"The security of the third-party vendor is what you're relying on.\"\n\nHBO is still investigating how hackers broke into its computer system. They stole episodes of Larry David's Curb Your Enthusiasm and Ballers, a person familiar with the matter said at the time. They also stole an executive's emails and a summary of an unaired episode of Game of Thrones, according to Variety.\n\nAfter receiving a ransom demand, an HBO executive emailed the hacker on July 27 offering US$250,000 (RM1.07 million) as payment for finding a security flaw, according to a copy of the message obtained by Bloomberg. HBO asked the hacker to extend the deadline for a week while the company arranged a payment in bitcoin. That was a stalling effort, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. Variety reported on the email earlier.\n\nThe hackers don't appear to have breached the company's entire email system, Chief Executive Officer Richard Plepler told staff last week. The network, owned by Time Warner Inc, declined to make any additional comment.\n\nFor Hollywood, hackers are threatening both reputations and businesses. A stolen movie that appears online before appearing in theatres loses 19 per cent of its box-office revenue on average compared with films that are pirated after they're released, according to a study by professors at University of Maryland and Carnegie Mellon University. People may not be willing to subscribe to Netflix or HBO if they can watch their favourite shows and movies online for free.\n\nRansom demands\n\nWhat's more, the wave of attacks is forcing media executives to confront a thorny question: Should they pay ransoms to hackers to get their content back?\n\nThe FBI says that's always a bad idea.\n\n\"We believe it perpetuates the crime in general,\" FBI spokeswoman Laura Eimiller said.\n\nThere's also no guarantee paying the ransom will work. In April, Netflix refused to pay a hacker who stole unreleased episodes of Orange Is the New Black. Larson Studios, which worked with Netflix, told Variety it paid the ransom, about US$50,000, in bitcoin. The hacker, who went by the name TheDarkOverlord, dumped the stolen episodes online anyway.\n\nLarson Studios didn't respond to a request for comment, while a Netflix official said only that the company is \"constantly working to improve our security.\"\n\nIn another high profile case this year, hackers threatened to leak a stolen copy of Disney's new Pirates of the Caribbean if the company didn't pay a ransom. The company refused, and Chief Executive Officer Bob Iger said later he believed it was all a hoax.\n\nEven so, with millions of dollars at stake, some companies may decide paying is the best option, said Gary Davis, chief consumer security evangelist at the security firm McAfee Inc.\n\n\"If they got access to something like Game of Thrones and I can pay them a couple million dollars to get that back, there's probably a good use case,\" he said.\n\nThe Sony attack, which embarrassed studio executives after private emails were made public, was linked by the FBI to North Korea, which allegedly was retaliating for The Interview, a film about a fictional plot to assassinate leader Kim Jong-un. Some studios have reportedly removed Russian President Vladimir Putin as a character in films because they're concerned they'll suffer a similar fate.\n\nSony has learned from that attack. Michael Lynton, former chief executive officer of Sony Entertainment, started transferring emails off his computer every 10 days.\n\n\"To me, that's the solution,\" Lynton said at event hosted by Lerer Hippeau Ventures in May. \"Put it in a drawer and lock the drawer.\" -- Bloomberg", "timeCrawl": "01:58:00", "sim": 0.9725490212440491, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 221, "date": "2017-08-13", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 227}, {"textStart": 2362, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 2369}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8862144", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "id": 107, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "id": 342, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

"The Interview (2014 film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "467209", "score": 1}], "time": "07:34:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "A-A+\n\nBy Gerry Smith\n\nBloomberg\n\nSony. Netflix. And now, HBO.\n\nWhile the 2014 hacking at Sony Pictures pushed entertainment giants to take computer security more seriously, recent incidents have exposed weaknesses throughout Hollywood's food chain. Last week, as HBO investigated a cyberattack on its own systems, an unaired episode of its hit show \"Game of Thrones\" appeared online following an unrelated breach at a pay-TV partner in India. In April, when 10 episodes of Netflix's \"Orange Is the New Black\" leaked, the incident was traced to a contractor.\n\nCybercrime is a growing problem for many industries, but Hollywood is especially vulnerable because of the long chain of people who work on a show or movie in post-production, experts say. Studios rely on an army of freelancers for everything from special effects to musical scores, creating a vast network of targets for hackers. Bringing those workers in-house is an option but would be expensive and could limit the talent studios can tap.\n\n\"Hollywood will have to recognize this will continue to grow and be an issue,\" said Mike Orosz, who studies cyber risk as research director at the University of Southern California's Information Sciences Institute.\n\nHBO requires employees to have two-factor authentication and strong passwords for their computers. They also undergo security awareness training. But the company works with many post-production freelancers that handle sensitive information on personal email accounts and personal devices, raising security concerns, according to a former employee who asked not to be identified discussing an internal matter.\n\n\"Once the content is out of your hands, it's truly out of your hands,\" Orosz said. \"The security of the third-party vendor is what you're relying on.\"\n\nHBO is still investigating how hackers broke into its computer system. They stole episodes of Larry David's \"Curb Your Enthusiasm\" and \"Ballers,\" a person familiar with the matter said at the time. They also stole an executive's emails and a summary of an unaired episode of \"Game of Thrones,\" according to Variety.\n\nThe hackers don't appear to have breached the company's entire email system, Chief Executive Officer Richard Plepler told staff last week. The network, owned by Time Warner Inc., declined to make any additional comment.\n\nFor Hollywood, hackers are threatening both reputations and businesses. A stolen movie that appears online before appearing in theaters loses 19 percent of its box-office revenue on average compared with films that are pirated after they're released, according to a study by professors at University of Maryland and Carnegie Mellon University. People may not be willing to subscribe to Netflix or HBO if they can watch their favorite shows and movies online for free.\n\nWhat's more, the wave of attacks is forcing media executives to confront a thorny question: Should they pay ransoms to hackers to get their content back? The HBO hackers released an email from an HBO executive last week showing a willingness to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000.\n\nThe FBI says that's always a bad idea.\n\n\"We believe it perpetuates the crime in general,\" FBI spokeswoman Laura Eimiller said.\n\nThere's also no guarantee paying the ransom will work. In April, Netflix refused to pay a hacker who stole unreleased episodes of \"Orange Is the New Black.\" Larson Studios, which worked with Netflix, told Variety it paid the ransom, about $50,000, in bitcoin. The hacker, who went by the name TheDarkOverlord, dumped the stolen episodes online anyway.\n\nLarson Studios didn't respond to a request for comment, while a Netflix official said only that the company is \"constantly working to improve our security.\"\n\nIn another high-profile case this year, hackers threatened to leak a stolen copy of Disney's new \"Pirates of the Caribbean\" if the company didn't pay a ransom. The company refused, and Chief Executive Officer Bob Iger said later he believed it was all a hoax.\n\nEven so, with millions of dollars at stake, some companies may decide paying is the best option, said Gary \u00adDavis, chief consumer security evangelist at the security firm McAfee Inc.\n\n\"If they got access to something like 'Game of Thrones' and I can pay them a couple million dollars to get that back, there's probably a good use case,\" he said.\n\nThe Sony attack, which embarrassed studio executives after private emails were made public, was linked by the FBI to North Korea, which allegedly was retaliating for \"The Interview,\" a film about a fictional plot to assassinate leader Kim Jong Un. Some studios have reportedly removed Russian President Vladimir Putin as a character in films because they're concerned they'll suffer a similar fate.\n\nSony has learned from that attack. Michael Lynton, former chief executive officer of Sony Entertainment, started transferring emails off his computer every 10 days.\n\n\"To me, that's the solution,\" Lynton said at event hosted by Lerer Hippeau Ventures in May. \"Put it in a drawer and lock the drawer.\"\n\n17935913", "timeCrawl": "07:34:00", "sim": 0.9686274528503418, "extractedDates": null, "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8885398", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "id": 107, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "id": 342, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

"The Interview (2014 film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "467209", "score": 1}], "time": "22:40:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nSony. Netflix. And now, HBO.\n\nWhile the 2014 hacking at Sony Pictures pushed entertainment giants to take computer security more seriously, recent incidents have exposed weaknesses throughout Hollywood's food chain. Last week, as HBO investigated a cyberattack on its own systems, an unaired episode of its hit show \"Game of Thrones\" appeared online following an unrelated breach at a pay-TV partner in India. In April, when 10 episodes of Netflix Inc.'s \"Orange Is the New Black\" leaked, the incident was traced to a contractor.\n\nCybercrime is a growing problem for many industries, but Hollywood is especially vulnerable because of the long chain of people who work on a show or movie in post-production, experts say. Studios rely on an army of freelancers for everything from special effects to musical scores, creating a vast network of targets for hackers. Bringing those workers in-house is an option but would be expensive and could limit the talent studios can tap.\n\n\"Hollywood will have to recognize this will continue to grow and be an issue,\" said Mike Orosz, who studies cyber risk as research director at the University of Southern California's Information Sciences Institute.\n\nHBO requires employees to have two-factor authentication and strong passwords for their computers. They also undergo security awareness training. But the company works with many post-production freelancers that handle sensitive information on personal email accounts and personal devices, raising security concerns, according to a former employee who asked not to be identified discussing an internal matter.\n\n\"Once the content is out of your hands, it's truly out of your hands,\" Orosz said. \"The security of the third-party vendor is what you're relying on.\"\n\nHBO is still investigating how hackers broke into its computer system. They stole upcoming episodes of Larry David's \"Curb Your Enthusiasm\" and \"Ballers,\" a person familiar with the matter said at the time. They also stole an executive's emails and a summary of an unaired episode of \"Game of Thrones,\" according to Variety.\n\nThe hackers don't appear to have breached the company's entire email system,Chief Executive Officer Richard Plepler told staff last week. The network, owned by Time Warner Inc., declined to make any additional comment.\n\nFor Hollywood, hackers are threatening both reputations and businesses. A stolen movie that appears online before appearing in theaters loses 19 percent of its box-office revenue on average compared with films that are pirated after they're released, according to a study by professors at University of Maryland and Carnegie Mellon University. People may not be willing to subscribe to Netflix or HBO if they can watch their favorite shows and movies online for free.\n\nWhat's more, the wave of attacks is forcing media executives to confront a thorny question: Should they pay ransoms to hackers to get their content back? A hacker released a video this week demanding that HBO pay up to avoid further disclosures.\n\nThe FBI says that's always a bad idea.\n\n\"We believe it perpetuates the crime in general,\" FBI spokeswoman Laura Eimiller said.\n\nThere's also no guarantee paying the ransom will work. In April, Netflix refused to pay a hacker who stole unreleased episodes of \"Orange Is the New Black.\" Larson Studios, which worked with Netflix, told Variety it paid the ransom, about $50,000, in bitcoin. The hacker, who went by the name TheDarkOverlord, dumped the stolen episodes online anyway.\n\nLarson Studios didn't respond to a request for comment, while a Netflix official said only that the company is \"constantly working to improve our security.\"\n\nIn another high profile case this year, hackers threatened to leak a stolen copy of Disney's new \"Pirates of the Caribbean\" if the company didn't pay a ransom. The company refused, and Chief Executive Officer Bob Iger said later he believed it was all a hoax.\n\nEven so, with millions of dollars at stake, some companies may decide paying is the best option, said Gary Davis,chief consumer security evangelist at the security firm McAfee Inc.\n\n\"If they got access to something like Game of Thrones' and I can pay them a couple million dollars to get that back, there's probably a good use case,\" he said.\n\nThe Sony attack, which embarrassed studio executives after private emails were made public, was linked by the FBI to North Korea, which allegedly was retaliating for \"The Interview,\" a film about a fictional plot to assassinate leader Kim Jong Un. Some studios have reportedly removed Russian President Vladimir Putin as a character in films because they're concerned they'll suffer a similar fate.\n\nSony has learned from that attack. Michael Lynton, former chief executive officer of Sony Entertainment, started transferring emails off his computer every 10 days.\n\n\"To me, that's the solution,\" Lynton said at event hosted by Lerer Hippeau Ventures in May. \"Put it in a drawer and lock the drawer.\"\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORERead or Share this story: http://detne.ws/2uyE432", "timeCrawl": "22:40:00", "sim": 0.9647058844566345, "extractedDates": null, "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "id": "8713471", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "id": 107, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "id": 342, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}
{"uri": "708245179", "source": {"uri": "asianage.com", "id": "2273", "title": "The Asian Age"}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:44:00Z", "lang": "eng", "image": "http://images.asianage.com/images/aa-Cover-8djga14n9pgdgdkg3ga03kq0c6-20170715222159.Medi.jpeg", "eventUri": "eng-3347299", "title": "Leaked email shows HBO negotiating with hackers", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12", "storyUri": "eng-3356104", "url": "http://www.asianage.com/technology/in-other-news/120817/leaked-email-shows-hbo-negotiating-with-hackers.html", "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California", "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, "score": 3, "id": "227084", "type": "loc", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email", "label": {"eng": "Email"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "302685", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix", "label": {"eng": "Netflix"}, "type": "org", "id": "302687", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "label": {"eng": "Chief "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hacker_(computer_security)", "label": {"eng": "Hacker (computer security)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "304787", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO", "label": {"eng": "HBO"}, "type": "org", "id": "306249", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "307060", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulnerability_(computing)", "label": {"eng": "Vulnerability (computing)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "311951", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_Is_the_New_Black", "label": {"eng": "Orange Is the New Black"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "315526", "score": 2}], "time": "03:44:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multi-million dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"", "timeCrawl": "03:44:00", "sim": 0.9647058844566345, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "freq": 2, "amb": false, "textEnd": 11, "date": "2017-07-27", "textStart": 4}, {"textStart": 2070, "date": "2017-07-31", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 2077}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "id": "8739263", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "id": 62, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "id": 65, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "id": 66, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "id": 1057, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "307060", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variety_(magazine)", "311807", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_crime", "label": {"eng": "Computer crime"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "312212", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Maryland,_College_Park", "label": {"eng": "University of Maryland, College Park"}, "type": "org", "id": "314163", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_Is_the_New_Black", "label": {"eng": "Orange Is the New Black"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "315526", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_conglomerate", "label": {"eng": "Media conglomerate"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "317512", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Entertainment", "label": {"eng": "Sony Pictures Entertainment"}, "type": "org", "id": "340675", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Request_for_Comments", "label": {"eng": "Request for Comments"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "348890", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curb_Your_Enthusiasm", "label": {"eng": "Curb Your Enthusiasm"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "357318", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_David", "label": {"eng": "Larry David"}, "type": "person", "id": "357332", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Sciences_Institute", "label": {"eng": "Information Sciences Institute"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "392222", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Iger", "label": {"eng": "Bob Iger"}, "type": "person", "id": "393556", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Interview_(2014_film)", "label": {"eng": "The Interview (2014 film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "467209", "score": 1}], "time": "08:13:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "While the 2014 hacking at Sony Pictures pushed entertainment giants to take computer security more seriously, recent incidents have exposed weaknesses throughout Hollywood's food chain. Last week, as HBO investigated a cyberattack on its own systems, an unaired episode of its hit show Game of Thrones appeared online following an unrelated breach at a pay-TV partner in India. In April, when 10 episodes of Netflix Inc.'s Orange Is the New Black leaked, the incident was traced to a contractor.\n\nCybercrime is a growing problem for many industries, but Hollywood is especially vulnerable because of the long chain of people who work on a show or movie in post-production, experts say. Studios rely on an army of freelancers for everything from special effects to musical scores, creating a vast network of targets for hackers. Bringing those workers in-house is an option but would be expensive and could limit the talent studios can tap.\n\n\"Hollywood will have to recognize this will continue to grow and be an issue,\" said Mike Orosz, who studies cyber risk as research director at the University of Southern California's Information Sciences Institute.\n\nHBO requires employees to have two-factor authentication and strong passwords for their computers. They also undergo security awareness training. But the company works with many post-production freelancers that handle sensitive information on personal email accounts and personal devices, raising security concerns, according to a former employee who asked not to be identified discussing an internal matter.\n\n\"Once the content is out of your hands, it's truly out of your hands,\" Orosz said. \"The security of the third-party vendor is what you're relying on.\"\n\nHBO is still investigating how hackers broke into its computer system. They stole episodes of Larry David's Curb Your Enthusiasm and Ballers, a person familiar with the matter said at the time. They also stole an executive's emails and a summary of an unaired episode of Game of Thrones, according to Variety.\n\nAfter receiving a ransom demand, an HBO executive emailed the hacker on 27 July offering $250,000 as payment for finding a security flaw, according to a copy of the message obtained by Bloomberg. HBO asked the hacker to extend the deadline for a week while the company arranged a payment in bitcoin. That was a stalling effort, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. Variety reported on the email earlier.\n\nThe hackers don't appear to have breached the company's entire email system, chief executive officer Richard Plepler told staff last week. The network, owned by Time Warner Inc., declined to make any additional comment.\n\nFor Hollywood, hackers are threatening both reputations and businesses. A stolen movie that appears online before appearing in theaters loses 19% of its box-office revenue on average compared with films that are pirated after they're released, according to a study by professors at University of Maryland and Carnegie Mellon University. People may not be willing to subscribe to Netflix or HBO if they can watch their favourite shows and movies online for free.\n\nRansom demands\n\nWhat's more, the wave of attacks is forcing media executives to confront a thorny question: Should they pay ransoms to hackers to get their content back?\n\nThe FBI says that's always a bad idea. \"We believe it perpetuates the crime in general,\" FBI spokeswoman Laura Eimiller said.\n\nThere's also no guarantee paying the ransom will work. In April, Netflix refused to pay a hacker who stole unreleased episodes of Orange Is the New Black. Larson Studios, which worked with Netflix, told Variety it paid the ransom, about $50,000, in bitcoin. The hacker, who went by the name TheDarkOverlord, dumped the stolen episodes online anyway.\n\nLarson Studios didn't respond to a request for comment, while a Netflix official said only that the company is \"constantly working to improve our security.\"\n\nIn another high profile case this year, hackers threatened to leak a stolen copy of Disney's new Pirates of the Caribbean if the company didn't pay a ransom. The company refused, and chief executive officer Bob Iger said later he believed it was all a hoax.\n\nEven so, with millions of dollars at stake, some companies may decide paying is the best option, said Gary Davis, chief consumer security evangelist at the security firm McAfee Inc.\n\n\"If they got access to something like Game of Thrones and I can pay them a couple million dollars to get that back, there's probably a good use case,\" he said.\n\nThe Sony attack, which embarrassed studio executives after private emails were made public, was linked by the FBI to North Korea, which allegedly was retaliating for The Interview, a film about a fictional plot to assassinate leader Kim Jong Un. Some studios have reportedly removed Russian President Vladimir Putin as a character in films because they're concerned they'll suffer a similar fate.\n\nSony has learned from that attack. Michael Lynton, former chief executive officer of Sony Entertainment, started transferring emails off his computer every 10 days.\n\n\"To me, that's the solution,\" Lynton said at event hosted by Lerer Hippeau Ventures in May. \"Put it in a drawer and lock the drawer.\" Bloomberg", "timeCrawl": "08:13:00", "sim": 0.95686274766922, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2102, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 2109}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "id": "8762913", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "id": 107, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Consultants", "id": 342, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}
{"uri": "708218042", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "id": "104", "title": "Washington Post"}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:11:00Z", "lang": "eng", "image": "https://img.washingtonpost.com/rf/image_1484w/2010-2019/Wires/Online/2017-08-11/AP/Images/HBO_Hack_66577.jpg-417f9.jpg?t=20170517", "eventUri": "eng-3347299", "title": "Leaked email shows HBO negotiating with hackers", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12", "storyUri": "eng-3356104", "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/leaked-email-shows-hbo-negotiating-with-hackers/2017/08/11/337b32c6-7ee6-11e7-b2b1-aeba62854dfa_story.html", "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California", "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, "score": 3, "id": "227084", "type": "loc", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email", "label": {"eng": "Email"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "302685", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix", "label": {"eng": "Netflix"}, "type": "org", "id": "302687", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "label": {"eng": "Chief "North America"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Departments_of_France", "label": {"eng": "Departments of France"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "303465", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_security", "label": {"eng": "Computer security"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "304781", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hacker_(computer_security)", "label": {"eng": "Hacker (computer security)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "304787", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO", "label": {"eng": "HBO"}, "type": "org", "id": "306249", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "307060", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_Is_the_New_Black", "label": {"eng": "Orange Is the New Black"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "315526", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hackers_(film)", "label": {"eng": "Hackers (film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "347396", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug_bounty_program", "label": {"eng": "Bug bounty program"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "1278345", "score": 3}], "time": "21:11:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "BOSTON -- Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multi-million dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"\n\n__\n\nArbel reported from New York.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "id": "1278345", "score": 3}], "time": "23:33:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "BOSTON - Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multimillion-dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"\n\nArbel reported from New York.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulnerability_(computing)", "label": {"eng": "Vulnerability (computing)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "311951", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_Is_the_New_Black", "label": {"eng": "Orange Is the New Black"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "315526", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug_bounty_program", "label": {"eng": "Bug bounty program"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "1278345", "score": 3}], "time": "02:15:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multi-million dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"", "timeCrawl": "02:15:00", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 4, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 11}, {"textStart": 1559, "date": "2017-07-31", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 1566}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "id": "8732630", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "id": 62, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "id": 65, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "id": 66, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "id": 268, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "id": 1057, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

"title": "Leaked email shows HBO negotiating with hackers", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11", "storyUri": "eng-3356104", "url": "http://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/television/2017/08/leaked_email_shows_hbo_negotiating_with_hackers", "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California", "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, "score": 3, "id": "227084", "type": "loc", "label": {"eng": "California"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email", "label": {"eng": "Email"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "302685", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix", "label": {"eng": "Netflix"}, "type": "label": {"eng": "Hacker (computer security)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "304787", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO", "label": {"eng": "HBO"}, "type": "org", "id": "306249", "label": {"eng": "Hackers (film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "347396", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug_bounty_program", "label": {"eng": "Bug bounty program"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "1278345", "score": 3}], "time": "17:46:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "BOSTON -- Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multi-million dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"", "timeCrawl": "23:10:00", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 186, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 193}, {"textStart": 1741, "date": "2017-07-31", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 1748}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-11", "id": "8716758", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "id": 62, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "id": 65, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "id": 66, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Freeware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Freeware", "id": 306, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "id": 1057, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

"http://multifiles.pressherald.com/uploads/sites/4/2017/08/1239398_HBO_Hack_66577.jpg-417f9.jpg", "eventUri": "eng-3347299", "title": "Leaked email shows HBO negotiating with hackers - Portland Press Herald", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11", "storyUri": "eng-3356104", "url": "http://www.pressherald.com/2017/08/11/leaked-email-shows-hbo-negotiating-with-hackers/", "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, "score": 3, "id": "233", "type": "loc", "label": {"eng": "United States of "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix", "label": {"eng": "Netflix"}, "type": "org", "id": "302687", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "wiki", "id": "304781", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO", "label": {"eng": "HBO"}, "type": "org", "id": "306249", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "307060", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showtime_(TV_channel)", "label": {"eng": "Showtime (TV channel)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "313076", "score": 1}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolaj_Coster-Waldau", "label": {"eng": "Nikolaj Coster-Waldau"}, "type": "person", "id": "367117", "score": 3}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire_characters#Jaime_Lannister", "label": {"eng": "Jaime Lannister"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "796509", "score": 3}], "time": "23:09:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "BOSTON - Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nThis file image released by HBO shows Nikolaj Coster-Waldau as Jaime Lannister in an episode of \"Game of Thrones,\" which aired Aug. 6. Material hacked from HBO included scripts from five \"Game of Thrones\" episodes. Macall B. Polay/HBO via Associated Press Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multimillion-dollar ransom.\n\nHOW BAD IS THE HACK?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA ROUGH CHRONOLOGY\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from \"Game of Thrones\" episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHOLLYWOOD IN THE CROSSHAIRS\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's \"Orange is the New Black\" ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"\n\nArbel reported from New York.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hackers_(film)", "label": {"eng": "Hackers (film)"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "347396", "score": 5}], "time": "14:51:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them US$250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an executive with the firm who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a one-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of US$250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multimillion dollar ransom.\n\nIf Trump must start a nuclear war, at least let us finish Game of Thrones first\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its US$250,000 offer, the email raised questions on Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty programme,\" said Pablo Garcia, chief executive of FFRI North America. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for US$250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from Game of Thrones episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice-president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\n'Game of Thrones' script is leaked after HBO hack\n\nHBO has said that it is working with authorities and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's Orange is the New Black ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, chief executive of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"", "timeCrawl": "14:51:00", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 178, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 185}, {"textStart": 1770, "date": "2017-07-31", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 1777}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "id": "8806086", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "id": 62, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "id": 65, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "id": 66, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "id": 1057, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Roleplaying", "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Roleplaying", "id": 1189, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

"score": 3}], "time": "05:03:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "\u00a9 Hindustan Times Hackers this week released an email from HBO in which the company expressed willingness to pay them $250,000 as part of a negotiation over data swiped from HBO's servers.\n\nThe July 27 email was sent by John Beyler, an HBO executive who thanked the hackers for \"making us aware\" of previously unknown security vulnerabilities. The executive asked for a 1-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment. A person close to the investigation confirmed the authenticity of the email, but said it was an attempt to buy time and assess the situation. The same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multi-million dollar ransom.\n\nHow bad is the hack?\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data and whether HBO's reaction might encourage future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, California. \"They're being extorted. If it was a bug bounty, it'd be on the up and up.\"\n\nBeyler's email to the hackers said the company was working \"very hard\" to review all the material they provided, and also trying to figure out a way to make a large transaction in bitcoin, the hackers' preferred payment method.\n\n\"You have the advantage of having surprised us,\" Beyler wrote. \"In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.\"\n\nA rough chronology\n\nThe first HBO hack became publicly known on July 31. Beyler's email, sent several days earlier, might have been an attempt to make the problem go away without too much bad publicity for HBO, said Sanjay Goel, a professor at the University at Albany and chairman of its information technology management department.\n\n\"Hackers are not in this game for $250,000; this probably took them a lot of time and effort,\" Goel said. \"That's a very, very small amount in these kinds of negotiations.\"\n\nThen, on Monday, hackers using the name \"Mr. Smith\" posted a fresh cache of stolen HBO files online, and demanded that the network pay a ransom of several million dollars to prevent further such releases.\n\nThe leaks included scripts from Game of Thrones episodes and a month's worth of email from the account of HBO's vice president for film programming. There were also internal documents, including a report of legal claims against the network and job offer letters to top executives.\n\nHollywood in the crosshairs\n\nHBO has said that it is working with law enforcement and cybersecurity firms to investigate the attack, which is the latest to hit a Hollywood business. In April, a hacker claimed to have released episodes of Netflix's Orange is the New Black ahead of their official launch date.\n\nThe leaks so far have fallen well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nBut paying ransoms to hackers can be dangerous because it shows that being a bad-guy hacker is a good business, said cybersecurity expert Oren Falkowitz, CEO of Redwood City, California-based Area 1 Security. Companies would be better off investing in preventing email spear-fishing attempts and other hacking techniques, he said.\n\n\"The reason they got in this scenario is they didn't have the right pre-emption strategy,\" Falkowitz said. \"The next company, whether it's Showtime or Death Row Records or whomever, needs to see that they're going to wake up one day to this reality unless they confront it.\"", "timeCrawl": "05:03:00", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 195, "date": "2017-07-27", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 202}, {"textStart": 1750, "date": "2017-07-31", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 1757}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8873849", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/E-mail", "id": 62, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Shareware", "id": 65, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Internet", "id": 66, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "id": 268, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security", "id": 302, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Security/Internet", "id": 495, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Hacking", "id": 675, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Telecommunications/Services", "id": 1057, "wgt": 100}], "details": {}}

{"uri": "708252814", "source": {"uri": "deathrattlesports.com", "id": "19200", "title": "deathrattlesports.com"}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:03:00Z", "lang": "eng", "image": null, "eventUri": "eng-3347299", "title": "HBO offers $250000 as 'bounty payment' to hackers", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12", "storyUri": "eng-3347299", "url": "http://www.deathrattlesports.com/hbo-offers-250000-as-bounty-payment-to-hackers/3937", "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, "score": 4, "id": "233", "type": "loc", "label": {"eng": "United States of America"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "302718", "score": 1}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony", "label": {"eng": "Sony"}, "type": "org", "id": "302846", "score": 2}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Warner", "label": {"eng": "Time Warner"}, "type": "org", "id": "305829", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO", "label": {"eng": "HBO"}, "type": "org", "id": "306249", "score": 5}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones", "label": {"eng": "Game of Thrones"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "307060", "score": 4}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_television", "label": {"eng": "Cable television"}, "type": "wiki", "id": "313307", "score": 4}], "time": "16:03:00", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The hackers behind HBO's recent data breach have leaked an email in which the U.S. cable channel offered them $250,000 as a 'bounty payment,' it was reported Thursday.\n\nThe message from HBO, the Time Warner Inc cable unit that broadcasts 'Game of Thrones,' offers the money as part of a program in which 'white-hat professionals' are rewarded for identifying cyber security flaws, according to Variety.\n\nThe email was worded in a way that would allow HBO to stall for time while it assessed the situation, citing a source close to HBO's investigation.\n\nHBO also requested the hackers to extend a ransom payment deadline by one week.\n\n'You have the advantage of having surprised us,' the message from HBO reads. 'In the spirit of professional cooperation, we are asking you to extend your deadline for one week.'\n\nThe $250,000 sum is just 3-4 per cent of the 'six months salary' request made in the video letter by the hacker, who claims to make $12million to $15million per year.\n\nThey have threatened to release new data from the reach every Sunday until the sum is paid.\n\nThis week, that included the hackers releasing a months worth of emails from HBO's vice president and a synopsis of the upcoming episode of Game of Thrones.\n\nHBO, which previously acknowledged the theft of 'proprietary information,' said it's continuing to investigate and is working with police and cybersecurity experts.\n\nThe network said Monday that it still doesn't believe that its email system as a whole has been compromised.\n\nLast week, August 6's episode of Game of Thrones was released two days early but that was later pegged to a distribution partner in India, and not the hackers.\n\nSo far the HBO hack data dumps have been limited, falling well short of the chaos inflicted on Sony in 2014.\n\nIn that attack, hackers unearthed thousands of embarrassing emails and released personal information, including salaries and social security numbers, of nearly 50,000 current and former Sony employees.\n\nThose behind the HBO hack claim to have more data, including scripts, upcoming episodes of HBO shows and movies, and information damaging to HBO.\n\nIn the video directed to HBO CEO Richard Plepler, 'Mr. Smith' used white text on a black background to threaten further disclosures if HBO doesn't pay up.\n\nHBO did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.\n\nThe hack has come at a sensitive time for HBO, whose parent Time Warner is awaiting regulatory approval to sell itself The executive asked for a one-week delay and said HBO was willing to make a \"good faith\" payment of $250,000, calling it a \"bug bounty\" reward for IT professionals rather than a ransom.\n\nHBO declined to comment.\n\nThe same hackers have subsequently released two dumps of HBO material and demanded a multimillion-dollar ransom.\n\nWhether or not HBO ever intended to follow through with its $250,000 offer, the email raised questions Friday among security professionals about the importance of the data as well as how it will affect future attacks.\n\n\"It's interesting that they're spinning it as a bug bounty program,\" said Pablo Garcia, CEO of FFRI North America, based in Aliso Viejo, Calif. \"They're being extorted.
